.git/hooks/pre-rebase.sample

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 #!/bin/sh
00002 #
00003 # Copyright (c) 2006, 2008 Junio C Hamano
00004 #
00005 # The "pre-rebase" hook is run just before "git rebase" starts doing
00006 # its job, and can prevent the command from running by exiting with
00007 # non-zero status.
00008 #
00009 # The hook is called with the following parameters:
00010 #
00011 # $1 -- the upstream the series was forked from.
00012 # $2 -- the branch being rebased (or empty when rebasing the current branch).
00013 #
00014 # This sample shows how to prevent topic branches that are already
00015 # merged to 'next' branch from getting rebased, because allowing it
00016 # would result in rebasing already published history.
00017 
00018 publish=next
00019 basebranch="$1"
00020 if test "$#" = 2
00021 then
00022     topic="refs/heads/$2"
00023 else
00024     topic=`git symbolic-ref HEAD` ||
00025     exit 0 ;# we do not interrupt rebasing detached HEAD
00026 fi
00027 
00028 case "$topic" in
00029 refs/heads/??/*)
00030     ;;
00031 *)
00032     exit 0 ;# we do not interrupt others.
00033     ;;
00034 esac
00035 
00036 # Now we are dealing with a topic branch being rebased
00037 # on top of master.  Is it OK to rebase it?
00038 
00039 # Does the topic really exist?
00040 git show-ref -q "$topic" || {
00041     echo >&2 "No such branch $topic"
00042     exit 1
00043 }
00044 
00045 # Is topic fully merged to master?
00046 not_in_master=`git rev-list --pretty=oneline ^master "$topic"`
00047 if test -z "$not_in_master"
00048 then
00049     echo >&2 "$topic is fully merged to master; better remove it."
00050     exit 1 ;# we could allow it, but there is no point.
00051 fi
00052 
00053 # Is topic ever merged to next?  If so you should not be rebasing it.
00054 only_next_1=`git rev-list ^master "^$topic" ${publish} | sort`
00055 only_next_2=`git rev-list ^master           ${publish} | sort`
00056 if test "$only_next_1" = "$only_next_2"
00057 then
00058     not_in_topic=`git rev-list "^$topic" master`
00059     if test -z "$not_in_topic"
00060     then
00061         echo >&2 "$topic is already up-to-date with master"
00062         exit 1 ;# we could allow it, but there is no point.
00063     else
00064         exit 0
00065     fi
00066 else
00067     not_in_next=`git rev-list --pretty=oneline ^${publish} "$topic"`
00068     /usr/bin/perl -e '
00069         my $topic = $ARGV[0];
00070         my $msg = "* $topic has commits already merged to public branch:\n";
00071         my (%not_in_next) = map {
00072             /^([0-9a-f]+) /;
00073             ($1 => 1);
00074         } split(/\n/, $ARGV[1]);
00075         for my $elem (map {
00076                 /^([0-9a-f]+) (.*)$/;
00077                 [$1 => $2];
00078             } split(/\n/, $ARGV[2])) {
00079             if (!exists $not_in_next{$elem->[0]}) {
00080                 if ($msg) {
00081                     print STDERR $msg;
00082                     undef $msg;
00083                 }
00084                 print STDERR " $elem->[1]\n";
00085             }
00086         }
00087     ' "$topic" "$not_in_next" "$not_in_master"
00088     exit 1
00089 fi
00090 
00091 exit 0
00092 
00093 ################################################################
00094 
00095 This sample hook safeguards topic branches that have been
00096 published from being rewound.
00097 
00098 The workflow assumed here is:
00099 
00100  * Once a topic branch forks from "master", "master" is never
00101    merged into it again (either directly or indirectly).
00102 
00103  * Once a topic branch is fully cooked and merged into "master",
00104    it is deleted.  If you need to build on top of it to correct
00105    earlier mistakes, a new topic branch is created by forking at
00106    the tip of the "master".  This is not strictly necessary, but
00107    it makes it easier to keep your history simple.
00108 
00109  * Whenever you need to test or publish your changes to topic
00110    branches, merge them into "next" branch.
00111 
00112 The script, being an example, hardcodes the publish branch name
00113 to be "next", but it is trivial to make it configurable via
00114 $GIT_DIR/config mechanism.
00115 
00116 With this workflow, you would want to know:
00117 
00118 (1) ... if a topic branch has ever been merged to "next".  Young
00119     topic branches can have stupid mistakes you would rather
00120     clean up before publishing, and things that have not been
00121     merged into other branches can be easily rebased without
00122     affecting other people.  But once it is published, you would
00123     not want to rewind it.
00124 
00125 (2) ... if a topic branch has been fully merged to "master".
00126     Then you can delete it.  More importantly, you should not
00127     build on top of it -- other people may already want to
00128     change things related to the topic as patches against your
00129     "master", so if you need further changes, it is better to
00130     fork the topic (perhaps with the same name) afresh from the
00131     tip of "master".
00132 
00133 Let's look at this example:
00134 
00135            o---o---o---o---o---o---o---o---o---o "next"
00136           /       /           /           /
00137          /   a---a---b A     /           /
00138         /   /               /           /
00139            /   /   c---c---c---c B         /
00140           /   /   /             \         /
00141          /   /   /   b---b C     \       /
00142         /   /   /   /             \     /
00143     ---o---o---o---o---o---o---o---o---o---o---o "master"
00144 
00145 
00146 A, B and C are topic branches.
00147 
00148  * A has one fix since it was merged up to "next".
00149 
00150  * B has finished.  It has been fully merged up to "master" and "next",
00151    and is ready to be deleted.
00152 
00153  * C has not merged to "next" at all.
00154 
00155 We would want to allow C to be rebased, refuse A, and encourage
00156 B to be deleted.
00157 
00158 To compute (1):
00159 
00160     git rev-list ^master ^topic next
00161     git rev-list ^master        next
00162 
00163     if these match, topic has not merged in next at all.
00164 
00165 To compute (2):
00166 
00167     git rev-list master..topic
00168 
00169     if this is empty, it is fully merged to "master".
